title: Right to Equality
summary: All individuals are equal before the law without discrimination.
fullExplanation: The Right to Equality ensures that every person receives equal treatment and protection regardless of race, gender, religion, caste, disability, economic background, or social status.
examples: Equal voting rights for all citizens.
scenarios: A job applicant rejected due to caste.
Men and women paid differently for the same role.

title: Freedom of Expression
summary: The right to freely express opinions and ideas.
fullExplanation: You can express views, share opinions, discuss issues, and criticize authorities peacefully. This right maintains democratic accountability and supports an informed society.
scenarios: An activist arrested for sharing facts online.
Students suspended for peaceful criticism of school administration.
didYouKnow: Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights guarantees freedom of expression.

title: Right to Education
summary: Everyone has the right to free and compulsory education.
fullExplanation: Education must be accessible to all children and should promote respect for human rights, equality, and freedom.
scenarios: Girls forced to drop out of school.
didYouKnow: The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009, guarantees free education in India.

title: Right to Privacy
summary: Individuals have the right to protect personal information and private life.
fullExplanation: This includes confidentiality of personal conversations, digital data privacy, and freedom from surveillance unless legally justified.
scenarios: Unauthorized CCTV monitoring in private spaces.
didYouKnow: In 2017, the Supreme Court of India declared privacy as a fundamental right.
